elements.title: Layered Trust Verification Visual Stack: Photo Gallery, Guarantee Badge, and Host Card as Above-the-Fold Trust Triad
elements.problem: Susan demands physical inspection three times (2:14, 3:05, 3:42) because the listing's visual signifiers are insufficient to replace in-person verification. Her friend is flying from Oregon — the cost of a wrong decision includes an airline ticket, not just a booking fee. Susan's prior scam experiences ('you know how sometimes people give you all kind of run around,' 2:22) mean her System 1 default for remote housing is 'likely fraud.' Norman states that anti-affordances (the no-preview policy) must be discoverable and perceivable, with substitute signifiers prominently displayed. The listing page's visual hierarchy must place trust verification evidence — verified photos, cancellation guarantee, host identity — at the highest position in the visual hierarchy, above property features, amenities, and price. Currently, no visual pattern exists that structures trust evidence as the primary visual layer rather than supplementary detail.
elements.solution: Design the listing page's visual hierarchy so that trust verification occupies the top of the visual stack, with three distinct visual signifiers forming an above-the-fold trust triad: (1) A full-bleed verified photo gallery with a purple 'Verified by Split Lease' badge (--primary-purple background, white text, --rounded-pill shape) anchored to the gallery's top-left corner. Photos must cover the exact elements Susan asked about: room, bathroom (1:08), common areas, building entrance. The badge uses --shadow-purple-sm for subtle elevation to distinguish it from photo content. (2) A first-night cancellation guarantee badge displayed with equal visual weight to the nightly price. The badge uses --bg-off-white background with --secondary-purple text and a Feather 'shield' icon at --icon-sm size. It sits immediately beside or below the price, not in a separate section. Norman: 'Affordances exist even if they are not visible. For designers, their visibility is critical.' (3) A host identity card with verified photo (--avatar-md, --rounded-full), name in --font-weight-semibold, response time in --text-gray, and guest count. The card uses --shadow-sm elevation on --bg-white with --border-color border. These three signifiers must be perceivable within 6 seconds of page load without scrolling.

evidence.quote: I do have to see the room before she puts her tickets. I have to go and see the space and just to make sure that everything is legit. You know how sometimes people give you all kind of run around.
evidence.insight: Susan's demand for visual verification is a trust requirement rooted in prior negative experiences. The listing page's visual hierarchy must place verification evidence where the eye lands first — the photo gallery zone — not as supplementary detail below the fold.

evidence.quote: To be effective, affordances and anti-affordances have to be discoverable — perceivable. If an affordance or anti-affordance cannot be perceived, some means of signaling its presence is required: I call this property a signifier.
evidence.insight: The no-preview policy is an anti-affordance with no visual signifier. The trust triad serves as the perceivable substitute: verified photos replace in-person viewing, the cancellation badge replaces the safety of being able to walk away after seeing the space, and the host card replaces the face-to-face meeting. Each must be visually distinct and immediately scannable.

evidence.quote: If I like the room in the bathroom, I can, should have pictures. And she said, it's okay. I'll give you the deposit right there.
evidence.insight: Susan explicitly identifies photos as the acceptable visual substitute for physical inspection AND immediately couples it with readiness to pay. The visual design must treat the photo gallery as the primary conversion mechanism — the element that transforms distrust into deposit readiness.

evidence.quote: Signifiers communicate where the action should take place... signifiers must be perceivable, else they fail to function.
evidence.insight: The verification badge on photos, the guarantee badge near the price, and the host identity card are all signifiers that communicate trustworthiness. Each must be visually distinct from decorative elements — using the purple brand color, elevated shadow, and iconography that signals verification rather than marketing.

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. Verification badge: white text on --primary-purple (#31135D) = 13.5:1 contrast ratio (AAA). Guarantee badge: --secondary-purple text on --bg-off-white requires verification — rgb(109, 49, 194) on rgb(252, 250, 255) yields approximately 5.2:1 (AA pass). Host card text: --text-dark on --bg-white = 16.1:1 (AAA). All trust signifiers must pass AA at minimum because trust elements cannot be ambiguous or hard to read.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The eye sees the photo gallery first (largest visual element, full-width). Within the gallery, the verification badge is the first text element perceived (top-left anchor, high-contrast purple on photo). Below the gallery, the guarantee badge and price sit at the same visual level (equal font weight, adjacent positioning). The host identity card follows as a self-contained unit. Property features, amenities, and description begin only after all three trust signifiers are visible. The pattern is: TRUST first, DETAILS second.
elements.brand_alignment: The purple verification badge directly uses the brand's primary color (#31135D) as a trust signal, reinforcing the association between the Split Lease brand and verified quality. The guarantee badge uses --secondary-purple for interactive/actionable elements, consistent with the style guide's CTA color system. The host card uses neutral colors (--bg-white, --text-dark, --text-gray) to frame the host as a real person rather than a branded element. Purple-tinted shadows (--shadow-purple-sm) on the verification badge create a subtle brand glow that connects trust evidence to the Split Lease visual identity.

elements.title: Platform Identity Signifier: Persistent Visual Anchor Communicating the Non-Continuous Model
elements.problem: Susan misidentifies Split Lease as a real estate brokerage (4:55: 'Real estate Agent'). She does not understand the non-continuous nights model ('Like seven nights a week?' at 0:43). Norman warns that 'hand-lettered signs pasted on products are the equivalent of poor design' — when you need to explain what something is, the design itself has failed. The platform's visual identity carries no perceivable signifier that communicates 'part-time housing' to a first-time visitor. The system image is incoherent because no visual element consistently communicates what this service is across pages. Every page the guest encounters — landing, search results, listing detail — must carry a visually consistent identity signifier that functions like a wayfinding marker: it tells the guest 'you are in a part-time housing platform' before they evaluate any specific listing.
elements.solution: Design a persistent identity signifier that appears on every page, using consistent visual treatment to build recognition through repetition. The signifier is a compact badge or tagline that communicates the core model in the guest's vocabulary. Visual specification: (1) On the landing page, the identity signifier is the hero headline: 'Book the nights you need' in Inter --font-weight-bold at --text-4xl (36px), color --primary-purple. Below it, a one-line subtitle in Inter --font-weight-normal at --text-lg (18px), color --text-gray: 'Part-time rooms and apartments, by the night.' (2) On listing cards in search results, a compact schedule badge appears as the first text element below the photo: a pill-shaped label (--rounded-pill, --bg-off-white background, --text-purple text) reading 'Weeknights' or 'Flexible' or 'Mon-Fri' — the available schedule pattern in 1-2 words. (3) On the listing detail page, the same schedule badge appears as a subtitle directly below the listing title, before the price. The pattern is: the identity signifier uses a consistent visual treatment (purple text on off-white pill) across all pages so the guest recognizes it as a system-level marker, not a listing-specific detail.

evidence.quote: Real estate Agent.
evidence.insight: Susan's misidentification reveals that no visual element on the platform communicates its category. The identity signifier must be visually prominent enough that a 2-second glance at any page tells the guest 'this is a part-time housing platform,' not a real estate brokerage, not an Airbnb, not a hotel.

evidence.quote: The designer of the product and the person using the product form somewhat disconnected vertices of a triangle... the entire burden of communication is on the system image.
evidence.insight: The system image is the visual totality that the user perceives. If every page lacks a visual signifier for 'part-time housing,' the system image communicates nothing about the service category. The identity signifier must be as persistent as a logo — present on every page, consistently styled, immediately recognizable.

evidence.quote: Like seven nights a week?
evidence.insight: Susan's default conceptual model for housing is full-time occupancy. The identity signifier must visually interrupt this default model. The schedule badge ('Weeknights,' 'Mon-Fri') on every listing card serves as a repeated visual correction: this is NOT full-time, this is part-time, this is specific nights.

evidence.quote: People need some way of understanding the product or service they wish to use, some sign of what it is for, what is happening, and what the alternative actions are.
evidence.insight: The identity signifier is a signifier at the service level, not the component level. It does not signify a button or a form field — it signifies what the entire platform IS. Its visual treatment must be elevated above component-level badges through size, color, and placement.

elements.title: Space Composition Label: Three-Part Visual Signifier for Room Type, Bathroom, and Co-Occupancy
elements.problem: Susan's first three questions in the call are about space composition: 'Is it a full apartment or is it a bedroom?' (0:43), 'What about a bathroom?' (1:08), 'Would somebody else be in the place when she's there?' (1:20). These three questions — space type, bathroom privacy, co-occupancy — constitute the primary decision variables for shared housing. Yet conventional listing card designs lead with photos, price, and location. For a platform where many listings involve shared spaces, the guest's first question is not 'Where is it?' or 'How much?' but 'What am I sharing and with whom?' Norman's signifier principle demands that the answer to this question be perceivable without effort. The visual design must surface space composition as a scannable, standardized label that the guest can evaluate in under 2 seconds per listing card.
elements.solution: Design a three-part space composition label as the first text element on every listing card, immediately below the photo. The label uses a consistent visual format: three short descriptors separated by a mid-dot (·) character, each using a Feather icon prefix for rapid scanning. Visual specification: (1) Format: '[icon] Private Room · [icon] Private Bath · [icon] Host present evenings' — all on one line or wrapping to a maximum of two lines. (2) Typography: Inter --font-weight-medium at --text-sm (12px), color --text-dark for the space type and bathroom descriptors, color --text-gray for the co-occupancy descriptor. The co-occupancy element is intentionally softer because it is contextual information, not a hard attribute. (3) Icons: Feather 'home' for space type, Feather 'droplet' for bathroom, Feather 'users' for co-occupancy, all at --icon-xs (16px), color matching their text. (4) On the listing detail page, the same label appears as a horizontal bar below the listing title, with each descriptor expanding on tap/click to show details (e.g., 'Host present evenings' expands to 'Rita works 9-5. She is typically home evenings and weekends. Common areas are shared.'). (5) The label sits above price and location, because for shared housing, space composition is the prerequisite filter before budget evaluation.

evidence.quote: Is it a full apartment or is it a bedroom? ... What about a bathroom? ... Would somebody else be in the place when she's there?
evidence.insight: Susan asks three questions in rapid succession, all about space composition. These are not secondary details — they are the primary decision variables. The visual design must answer all three in a single scan line on every listing card.

evidence.quote: Signifiers communicate where the action should take place... signifiers must be perceivable, else they fail to function.
evidence.insight: The space composition label is a signifier that communicates what kind of space the listing affords. If the label is absent, buried, or requires reading a paragraph description, it fails as a signifier. The three-part format with icons enables perception in under 2 seconds.

evidence.quote: Would somebody else be in the place when she's there? ... She is going to be there, but she does, she goes out to go to work.
evidence.insight: Co-occupancy is temporal, not binary. 'Shared' is not a useful label; 'Host present evenings' is. The visual design must communicate WHEN sharing occurs, not just WHETHER sharing occurs.

evidence.quote: When the system image is incoherent or inappropriate, then the user cannot easily use the device.
evidence.insight: If photos show an empty apartment but the guest arrives to find a host and their belongings, the system image was incoherent. The space composition label prevents this by setting accurate visual expectations that align with the physical reality.

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. --text-dark (#1a1a1a) on --bg-white = 16.1:1 (AAA). --text-gray (#6b7280) on --bg-white = 4.6:1 (AA pass). elements.title: Natural-Language Duration and Schedule Selectors with Real-Time Visual Translation
elements.problem: Susan thinks in calendar months ('one month or two months,' 0:11) and weekday names ('Monday to Friday'). The platform requires night counts ('30 night minimum,' 1:35). Bryant performs the vocabulary translation twice in the call. Norman's mapping principle states that 'natural mapping, taking advantage of spatial analogies, leads to immediate understanding.' The proposal creation form's visual design must accept the guest's natural vocabulary and translate it visually in real time, the way Bryant did verbally. The visual challenge is: how to design input controls that feel like natural language (months, weekdays) while displaying the platform's internal calculation (night count, total price) as a secondary layer that builds, not breaks, the guest's conceptual model.
elements.solution: Design duration and schedule input controls as preset-based selectors with a real-time translation summary bar. Visual specification: (1) Schedule presets: a horizontal row of pill-shaped toggle buttons ('Weekdays', 'Weekends', 'Full Week', 'Custom'). Each pill uses --rounded-pill, --bg-light-gray when inactive, --secondary-purple background with --white text when active. Active state transitions use --transition-fast with --easing-ease. (2) Duration presets: a row of selectable cards ('About 1 month', 'About 2 months', '3+ months', 'Custom'). Each card uses --rounded-xl, --border-color border when inactive, --secondary-purple border with --bg-off-white background when active. (3) Translation summary bar: a horizontal bar below the selectors, --bg-light background with --rounded-lg, displaying the computed result in Inter --font-weight-medium at --text-base: 'Mon-Fri for 2 months = 40 nights · $X/night · $Y total'. The summary updates in real time as the guest modifies selections, with each change producing a subtle pulse animation (--transition-base, opacity 0.5 → 1.0) to draw attention to the updated value. (4) 'Custom' options reveal a calendar grid or individual day toggles only when tapped, keeping the default view clean. The calendar grid uses the day badge component from the style guide (--day-badge-selected-bg for active days).

evidence.quote: Like seven nights a week?
evidence.insight: Susan defaults to full-time because she has no visual model for part-time housing. The schedule presets ('Weekdays,' 'Weekends') serve as visual signifiers for the part-time concept — the guest does not need to understand 'non-continuous nights,' they just need to tap the button that matches their pattern.

evidence.quote: Natural mapping, taking advantage of spatial analogies, leads to immediate understanding.
evidence.insight: Pill-shaped preset buttons are a natural mapping: each button represents one recognizable schedule pattern, and tapping it is the equivalent of saying 'Monday to Friday.' A number field labeled 'minimum nights' is an arbitrary mapping that requires cognitive translation.

evidence.quote: Rita would require a 30 night minimum... five nights a week for like two months would be something that would, could work.
evidence.insight: Bryant computes the translation verbally. The translation summary bar performs this same function visually: it shows both the guest's natural selection ('Mon-Fri for 2 months') and the platform's computation ('40 nights at $X'), maintaining transparency and building the correct conceptual model.

evidence.quote: Feedback must be immediate: even a delay of a tenth of a second can be disconcerting.
evidence.insight: The real-time summary update with pulse animation provides Norman's immediate feedback: the guest sees the consequence of their selection (night count, total cost) within 100ms. No spinner, no page reload, no delay.

elements.title: Negotiation Timeline: Visual Progress States with Prioritized Feedback Urgency
elements.problem: The Susan call contains a real-time negotiation with immediate verbal feedback at every exchange. The platform's negotiation is asynchronous — the guest submits a proposal and waits hours or days. Norman states: 'Feedback must be immediate: even a delay of a tenth of a second can be disconcerting.' When the phone call drops for 20 seconds at 2:42-3:05, both parties scramble with 'Can you hear me?' — trust erodes instantly from feedback loss. The visual design challenge is: how to make an asynchronous process feel transparent and progressing, rather than silent and abandoned. Every moment in the negotiation must have a visible, informative signifier. The visual pattern must distinguish between different urgency levels — a counter-offer requiring action looks different from a 'still waiting' status — so the guest develops a visual vocabulary for negotiation states.
elements.solution: Design the negotiation status as a vertical timeline with discrete visual states, each with a distinct color and icon treatment that communicates urgency at a glance. Visual specification: (1) Timeline structure: a vertical line (2px, --border-color) with circular state nodes (--icon-sm size, 20px diameter) at each step. Completed states use a solid purple circle (--secondary-purple fill, Feather 'check' icon in white). The current state uses a larger pulsing circle (24px, --secondary-purple border, --bg-off-white fill) with a subtle pulse animation (scale 1.0 → 1.05, --transition-slow, infinite, ease-in-out). Future states use an empty circle (--border-color border, --bg-white fill). (2) State labels: each node has a one-line label (Inter --font-weight-semibold at --text-base, --text-dark) and a one-line context (Inter --font-weight-normal at --text-sm, --text-gray). Example: 'Host Reviewing' / 'Rita usually responds in 6 hours.' (3) Urgency differentiation: 'Your Turn' states use --accent-coral (proposed) or --protocol-danger as an attention color — the node circle uses coral/red border, the label is bolded, and a subtle left-border accent (3px, --accent-coral) highlights the entire row. 'Still Waiting' states use the neutral pulse. 'Resolved' states (accepted/declined) use --secondary-purple for acceptance or --text-gray for decline. (4) Counter-offer changes are shown as an inline diff: changed terms highlighted with --bg-off-white background and --secondary-purple left border, unchanged terms dimmed to --text-light-gray.

evidence.quote: Can you hear me, Susan? Me? Yep. Can you hear me? No, I, yeah. You're you're back. I can hear you. Can you hear me? Yes. I can hear you.
evidence.insight: A 20-second feedback gap causes immediate anxiety. The pulsing current-state node is the visual equivalent of a heartbeat — it communicates 'the system is alive and processing' even when nothing has changed, preventing the 'Can you hear me?' anxiety in the digital context.

evidence.quote: Feedback has to be planned. All actions need to be confirmed, but in a manner that is unobtrusive. Feedback must also be prioritized, so that unimportant information is presented in an unobtrusive fashion, but important signals are presented in a way that does capture attention.
evidence.insight: The urgency differentiation (purple for routine, coral/red for action-required) implements Norman's feedback prioritization. Routine states (host reviewing, proposal sent) are calm purple. Action-required states (your turn, counter-offer) use the warm accent color to capture attention without alarming.

evidence.quote: I'll be in contact with Rita. And like I said, I'll keep you updated.
evidence.insight: Bryant's human promise of ongoing updates is replaced by the timeline's visual persistence — the guest can return to the timeline at any time and immediately see the current state, the context, and the next expected event. No human promise needed.

evidence.quote: Feedback must be immediate: even a delay of a tenth of a second can be disconcerting. If the delay is too long, people often give up, going off to do other activities.
evidence.insight: The subtle pulse animation on the current state node provides continuous visual feedback that the process is active, even during long waits. This is the visual equivalent of a loading indicator, but softer and more persistent — it does not demand attention, it simply confirms aliveness.

Completed node: white check icon on --secondary-purple = approximately 6.3:1 (AA pass). The pulse animation must respect prefers-reduced-motion: when reduced motion is active, replace the pulse with a static purple ring (--secondary-purple border, no animation).
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The eye scans the timeline top-to-bottom, with the pulsing current-state node drawing primary attention (motion attracts the eye). Within each state, the label is read first (semibold, dark), then the context (regular, gray). 'Your Turn' states break the scan pattern with the coral accent, pulling the eye to the action-required state regardless of its position in the timeline. Completed states recede (check icon, no motion) so the current and next states dominate the visual field.
elements.brand_alignment: The timeline uses --secondary-purple for progress and completion states, consistent with the style guide's use of this color for positive interactive outcomes. The --border-color line maintains the understated structural aesthetic of the style guide. The proposed warm urgency accent (--accent-coral) aligns with Paula Scher's proposed color revision that adds warmth to balance the cool purple palette. Purple-tinted shadows on the pulsing node (--shadow-purple-sm) subtly reinforce the brand identity even in status communication. The prefers-reduced-motion support follows the style guide's accessibility requirements.

elements.title: Move-In House Manual: Chronological Visual Sequence with Persistent Cancellation Safety Banner
elements.problem: Susan's friend is flying from Oregon with no prior physical experience of the space. At move-in, the gap between digital signifiers (listing photos, description) and physical reality is maximum. Susan's entire call is organized around preventing a catastrophic move-in failure. Norman distinguishes between 'knowledge in the head' (what the guest remembers) and 'knowledge in the world' (what is available at the moment of action). The House Manual must deliver knowledge-in-the-world at the exact moment the guest needs it, organized by the guest's physical action sequence at arrival, not by topic category. The cancellation guarantee — which Bryant improvised at 3:16 — must be the most visually prominent element during the first 24 hours, because it is the safety net that made the entire booking possible. The visual design challenge is: how to present a multi-step reference document that feels like a guided walkthrough on a phone screen, with one clear action per view and a persistent safety signal.
elements.solution: Design the House Manual as a mobile-first stepped sequence with a persistent cancellation guarantee banner. Visual specification: (1) Stepped sequence: a vertically scrolling page with numbered step cards, each occupying roughly one screen height. Each card has a step number (Inter --font-weight-bold at --text-2xl, --primary-purple, opacity 0.15 as a large background numeral), a step title (Inter --font-weight-semibold at --text-lg, --text-dark), and 3-4 data points (Inter --font-weight-normal at --text-base, --text-description). Steps: 1-Access, 2-Verify, 3-Connect, 4-Safety Net, 5-Settle, 6-Explore. (2) Persistent cancellation banner: a fixed-position bar at the bottom of the viewport during the first 24 hours. --gradient-purple-primary background (linear-gradient from #31135D to #5a2d8f), white text (Inter --font-weight-semibold at --text-sm), Feather 'shield' icon, message: 'Not what you expected? Cancel within 24 hours.' The banner uses --shadow-dark-sm for upward shadow to distinguish it from content. After 24 hours, the banner transitions (--transition-slow) to a dismissible notification and then disappears. (3) Step 2 (Verify) contains a visual checklist comparing listing claims to physical reality. Each item has a Feather 'check-circle' icon (--secondary-purple when confirmed, --border-color when pending) and a one-line label matching the listing's primary claims: 'Private bathroom,' 'Private room,' 'Wi-Fi works.' (4) The current step is visually emphasized: --bg-white card with --shadow-md elevation, while completed steps collapse to --bg-light with --shadow-sm. Upcoming steps show only their title and number, expanding as the guest progresses.

evidence.quote: I have to go and see the space and just to make sure that everything is legit. You know how sometimes people give you all kind of run around.
evidence.insight: Susan's anxiety is about the signifier-to-reality gap. The verification checklist (Step 2) directly addresses this by giving the guest a structured visual tool to confirm the space matches the listing. Each checked item transforms anxiety into confirmed trust.

evidence.quote: Two of the most important characteristics of good design are discoverability and understanding. Discoverability: Is it possible to even figure out what actions are possible and where and how to perform them?
evidence.insight: At move-in, every action (enter building, find room, connect Wi-Fi, contact host) must be discoverable from the House Manual. The stepped sequence makes each action discoverable in the order the guest needs it. The persistent banner makes the most critical affordance (cancellation) discoverable at all times.

evidence.quote: There would be something set up where if you come the first night and it's not something that would work, you have the flexibility to cancel.
evidence.insight: Bryant's improvised cancellation guarantee is the most important trust affordance in the journey. The persistent bottom banner makes it visually impossible to miss — it is the last thing the guest sees on every screen during the first 24 hours, reinforcing that they have a safety net.

evidence.quote: A good conceptual model allows us to predict the effects of our actions. Without a good model, we operate by rote, blindly.
evidence.insight: The numbered step cards create a conceptual model of the move-in process: the guest can see how many steps there are, which step they are on, and what comes next. This predictability reduces anxiety because the guest is never lost in the process — Norman's discoverability applied to a temporal sequence.

typography: Inter 700 (--font-weight-bold) at --text-2xl (28px) for step background numbers
Inter 600 (--font-weight-semibold) at --text-lg (18px) for step titles
Inter 400 (--font-weight-normal) at --text-base (14px) for step content
Inter 600 at --text-sm (12px) for cancellation banner text
Inter 500 at --text-base (14px) for checklist item labels
spacing: --spacing-2xl (24px) padding inside each step card
--spacing-lg (16px) gap between step cards
--spacing-md (12px) gap between checklist items
--spacing-lg (16px) padding inside the cancellation banner
--spacing-sm (8px) gap between banner icon and text
new_tokens_needed: --step-number-opacity: 0.08 — for the large background step numeral, needs to be visible enough to provide orientation but light enough not to interfere with step content readability. 0.15 may be too heavy on mobile screens; 0.08 provides subtler guidance
--banner-safe-area-bottom: env(safe-area-inset-bottom, 0px) — for the persistent cancellation banner on notch-equipped mobile devices, ensuring the banner does not overlap with the home indicator

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. Banner text: --white on --primary-purple (#31135D) = 13.5:1 (AAA). Step titles: --text-dark on --bg-white = 16.1:1 (AAA). Step content: --text-description (#374151) on --bg-white = approximately 9.4:1 (AAA). Checklist confirmed icons: --secondary-purple on --bg-white = approximately 5.2:1 (AA pass). The gradient banner must maintain at least 4.5:1 contrast for white text across its entire gradient range (#31135D to #5a2d8f — both exceed 7:1 for white text). The persistent banner must not obscure critical content — minimum 16px spacing between the last content element and the banner top edge.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: On initial load, the eye sees the active step card (highest elevation, white background, largest text). The cancellation banner is perceived peripherally (bottom-fixed, dark background, small text) as a safety signal that does not compete with the current step's content. As the guest progresses, completed steps collapse (lower elevation, muted background), keeping the active step as the visual focus. The background step numeral provides orientation ('I am on step 3 of 6') without demanding attention. The verification checklist icons (Step 2) draw the eye through their color change (gray → purple) as items are confirmed, creating visual momentum.
elements.brand_alignment: The gradient cancellation banner uses --gradient-purple-primary, directly from the style guide's brand gradient system. The step number treatment (primary purple at low opacity) creates a branded structural element that is uniquely Split Lease — the deep purple numeral as a watermark. Feather icons follow the style guide's icon library policy. The shadow elevation system (--shadow-sm for collapsed, --shadow-md for active) follows the style guide's shadow hierarchy. Mobile-first design with safe area handling aligns with the style guide's responsive approach.

elements.title: Proxy Booking Visual Mode: Dual-Role Interface with Role-Colored Information Zones
elements.problem: Susan is booking on behalf of a friend from Oregon. She says 'I can give you a deposit on her behalf' (2:34) and 'I'm setting up all appointments for her' (3:58-4:31). The platform's visual design assumes a single user viewing a single interface. When two roles (coordinator and occupant) share one booking, the interface must visually distinguish whose information is displayed and whose actions are available. Norman's signifier principle requires that 'people need some way of understanding what is happening and what the alternative actions are.' If the proxy sees her friend's check-in instructions mixed with her own payment details, the conceptual model breaks — she does not know which information is for her and which is for the friend. The visual design must create a role-aware interface that uses color, layout, and labeling to signify 'this is for you' versus 'this is for the occupant.'
elements.solution: Design a visual role-differentiation system that activates when 'Booking for someone else' is selected. Visual specification: (1) Role toggle at proposal start: two cards side by side — 'Booking for myself' (left, default active) and 'Booking for someone else' (right). Active card uses --secondary-purple border and --bg-off-white background. Inactive card uses --border-color border and --bg-white background. Each card has a Feather icon: 'user' for self, 'users' for proxy. (2) After proxy mode activation, the form splits into two visually distinct sections with a subtle color-coding system. Coordinator section: left-border accent (3px, --secondary-purple), label prefix 'Your' (Your name, Your contact, Your payment). Occupant section: left-border accent (3px, --accent-blue #4A90E2), label prefix using the occupant's name once entered or 'Guest' before entry (Guest name, Guest arrival date, Guest needs). (3) During active lease, the Stays Manager shows a role indicator badge at the top: 'Managing for [Friend's Name]' in a pill badge (--secondary-purple background, white text, --rounded-pill). Information panels are color-coded: coordinator-relevant panels (payment history, schedule management) have a subtle --bg-off-white background; occupant-relevant panels (check-in details, House Manual) have a subtle --bg-info (#f0f7ff) background. (4) Both roles can access all information, but their role-specific information is visually primary (full opacity, above the fold) while the other role's information is visually secondary (accessible via a 'View guest details' / 'View coordinator details' toggle).

evidence.quote: I like to see the place and I can give you a deposit on her behalf and she's ready to come whenever I can find her spot.
evidence.insight: Susan describes the split-responsibility pattern: she pays, the friend stays. The visual design must make this split legible — the coordinator's payment zone and the occupant's stay zone are visually distinct so neither person is confused about which information belongs to whom.

evidence.quote: People need some way of understanding the product or service they wish to use, some sign of what it is for, what is happening, and what the alternative actions are.
evidence.insight: The role-colored zones are signifiers that communicate 'this section is about YOUR role in the booking.' Without visual differentiation, the proxy user must read every label to determine relevance, violating the principle that signifiers must be perceivable without deliberate study.

evidence.quote: She's going to be out most of the day, you know, she has done appointments and all I'm setting up all appointments for her.
evidence.insight: During the active lease, Susan manages logistics while her friend occupies. The Stays Manager must visually prioritize management actions (scheduling, payment) for Susan and operational actions (check-in, house rules) for the friend. Role-colored backgrounds create this separation without requiring two separate interfaces.

evidence.quote: Good conceptual models are the key to understandable, enjoyable products: good communication is the key to good conceptual models.
evidence.insight: The two-role booking requires a two-role conceptual model. The visual color-coding (purple for coordinator, blue for occupant) creates a persistent visual vocabulary that the user learns once and recognizes throughout the journey. Purple = my actions. Blue = my friend's information.

--border-color (#e5e7eb) for inactive card border and section dividers
typography: Inter 600 (--font-weight-semibold) at --text-md (16px) for role toggle card labels
Inter 600 at --text-sm (12px) for role indicator badge on Stays Manager
Inter 500 (--font-weight-medium) at --text-base (14px) for section labels ('Your name', 'Guest arrival date')
Inter 400 at --text-base (14px) for form field values and panel content
spacing: --spacing-lg (16px) gap between the two role toggle cards
--spacing-2xl (24px) padding inside each form section
--spacing-md (12px) gap between the role accent border and the section content
--spacing-sm (8px) padding inside the role indicator badge
new_tokens_needed: --role-coordinator-accent: rgb(109, 49, 194) — aliased from --secondary-purple, creating a semantic token for the coordinator role color that can be updated independently if the role-coding system evolves
--role-occupant-accent: #4A90E2 — aliased from --accent-blue, creating a semantic token for the occupant role color

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. Coordinator accent: --secondary-purple as a 3px border is decorative and does not carry text, so contrast against background is not applicable for text. Occupant accent: --accent-blue as a 3px border follows the same principle. Role badge: --white text on --secondary-purple = approximately 6.3:1 (AA pass). All text within role-colored zones uses --text-dark on their respective backgrounds: --text-dark on --bg-off-white = approximately 15.8:1 (AAA); --text-dark on --bg-info = approximately 15.4:1 (AAA). The subtle background color difference between coordinator (warm purple tint) and occupant (cool blue tint) zones is a supplementary signal, not the sole differentiator — the label prefixes ('Your' vs. 'Guest') and left-border accents carry the primary semantic distinction.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The role toggle is the first visual element in the proxy booking flow — it establishes the conceptual model before any form fields appear. Once activated, the coordinator section appears first (purple accent, 'Your' prefix) because the coordinator is the active user. The occupant section follows (blue accent, 'Guest' prefix). During the active lease, the role indicator badge at the top of the Stays Manager establishes context immediately ('Managing for [Friend's Name]'), and the role-colored panels below organize information by relevance to the current user's role.
elements.brand_alignment: The coordinator role uses --secondary-purple, the brand's primary interactive color, because the coordinator is the actively transacting user. The occupant role uses --accent-blue, the style guide's secondary accent, maintaining the purple-centric palette while providing visual distinction. The --bg-off-white and --bg-info zone backgrounds are both already in the style guide's background color system, used here as role-semantic identifiers. The role indicator badge follows the pill badge convention (--rounded-pill) from the style guide. This approach avoids introducing new brand colors by reusing existing secondary colors with new semantic meaning.
